text: update: <https://twitter.com/crabl/status/1303193386359291904?s=21|https://twitter.com/crabl/status/1303193386359291904?s=21> starting to explore the TextKit stack a little more since it offers a pretty clean path to implementation. that said, if anyone has experience with implementing a custom NSTextStorage, i'd love to pick your brain for an hour!

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/crabl|@crabl>: "Layered Text" prototype rebuilt with SwiftUI: not sure whether I love the idea of showing "invisibles" (currently represented by unicode boxes) to indicate the positions of hidden layers, but it seems like a way to avoid a whole class of non-intuitive behaviors... thoughts? <https://pbs.twimg.com/ext_tw_video_thumb/1303193057911738370/pu/img/Sfmdq25gAm_OKM1X.jpg>
attachments.text: "Layered Text" prototype rebuilt with SwiftUI: not sure whether I love the idea of showing "invisibles" (currently represented by unicode boxes) to indicate the positions of hidden layers, but it seems like a way to avoid a whole class of non-intuitive behaviors... thoughts?

starting to explore the TextKit stack a little more since it offers a pretty clean path to implementation. that said, if anyone has experience with implementing a custom NSTextStorage, i'd love to pick your brain for an hour!

text: <@UG0EL18H3> Looks great. Not an expert on Text Kit, and you might already be well aware of it, but sometimes these older but still relevant docs are hard to find: <https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/Cocoa/Conceptual/TextStorageLayer/TextStorageLayer.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/10000087i|https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/Cocoa/Conceptual/TextStorageLayer/TextStorageLayer.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/10000087i>

attachments.title: Introduction to Text System Storage Layer Overview
attachments.text: Explains how the Cocoa text system stores the information it needs to lay out text.

text:
<@UUQ2EQW21> indeed, we find that there is a ton of possibilities when the editor is able to host dynamic adornments. For example:
<https://twitter.com/feenkcom/status/1303213233441067009>
<https://twitter.com/feenkcom/status/1303221842824626176>

attachments.fallback:
<https://twitter.com/feenkcom|@feenkcom>: We went through the trouble of implementing a whole new graphical stack in #gtoolkit because we wanted to enable new forms of expressions with and around code.

We paid particular attention to making the editor host new interactions.

E.g., compiler errors should be inlined. <https://pbs.twimg.com/ext_tw_video_thumb/1303213018612994054/pu/img/NkZlNUlYl7HdOG5W.jpg>
attachments.text:
We went through the trouble of implementing a whole new graphical stack in #gtoolkit because we wanted to enable new forms of expressions with and around code.

We paid particular attention to making the editor host new interactions.

E.g., compiler errors should be inlined.

attachments.fallback:
<https://twitter.com/feenkcom|@feenkcom>: We can benefit from more interaction inside the editor in many ways.

For example, here we have a compiler error inlined and we apply a fix it action that is offered right next to the problem.

#MoldableDevelopment with #gtoolkit <https://pbs.twimg.com/ext_tw_video_thumb/1303221677489352704/pu/img/QIUD7yBcQwATJnrg.jpg>
attachments.text:

text:
I was implementing this and got stuck part way with copy paste. What should happen with cut/copy/paste? Say you hide a few layers, then cut a visible chunk that surrounds some hidden text and paste it elsewhere. Does the hidden text:
1. Vanish
2. Travel with the cut/pasted text
3. Move to the end of the original cut location
Note that you may cut but never paste the text. Or you may copy/paste.

elements.text: I was implementing this and got stuck part way with copy paste. What should happen with cut/copy/paste? Say you hide a few layers, then cut a visible chunk that surrounds some hidden text and paste it elsewhere. Does the hidden text:
Vanish
Travel with the cut/pasted text
Move to the end of the original cut location
Note that you may cut but never paste the text. Or you may copy/paste.

text: I think that you should always favour preservation; so my intention here is to have it move to the end.  But I'm not certain, for sure.  Travelling might make sense too; but perhaps a that becomes a 'deep copy' operation with associated key stroke, etc.

elements.text: I think that you should always favour preservation; so my intention here is to have it move to the end.  But I'm not certain, for sure.  Travelling might make sense too; but perhaps a that becomes a 'deep copy' operation with associated key stroke, etc.

text: Yeah I'm thinking if something is hidden (like a hidden photoshop layer) you shouldn't be able to affect it - neither copy nor cut. So it would just drop to the end of the original cut location. Side note: traveling with the cut is also harder to implement for me because the clipboard needs to be modified to hold the hidden text. Finally if you cut, but never paste, you don't want to lose what you didn't see when cutting.

elements.text: Yeah I'm thinking if something is hidden (like a hidden photoshop layer) you shouldn't be able to affect it - neither copy nor cut. So it would just drop to the end of the original cut location. Side note: traveling with the cut is also harder to implement for me because the clipboard needs to be modified to hold the hidden text. Finally if you cut, but never paste, you don't want to lose what you didn't see when cutting.

text: OTOH, if you 'show' a layer and cut/paste, you want the layers to be preserved, not flattened, so we probably need to modify the clipboard to hold layered text anyway..

elements.text: OTOH, if you 'show' a layer and cut/paste, you want the layers to be preserved, not flattened, so we probably need to modify the clipboard to hold layered text anyway..

text: Quick update, I actually got in the Horizon beta and tried it out.  The final UI is pretty close to what we discussed before I left and some of my early ideas.  Specifically 2.5D with nested expressions, drag and drop from categories

elements.text: Quick update, I actually got in the Horizon beta and tried it out.  The final UI is pretty close to what we discussed before I left and some of my early ideas.  Specifically 2.5D with nested expressions, drag and drop from categories

text: Agreed; I was thinking about having a secondary buffer containing the layer for each character and storing/retrieving that with the text itself.  I have quite a narrow undo/redo layer; essentially there are only 2 commands that can modify text - Insert/Delete.  In these commands I already store the location of adornments/markers so that they can be replaced after a paste.  So that isn't hard; but it is hard to know what to do in each circumstance.

elements.text: Agreed; I was thinking about having a secondary buffer containing the layer for each character and storing/retrieving that with the text itself.  I have quite a narrow undo/redo layer; essentially there are only 2 commands that can modify text - Insert/Delete. text: so a lot of it is a pretty straight forward "scratch in VR" type system or a basic visual lisp editor, but it works pretty well.  Duplicate and move work using the same UI as the world building tools

elements.text: so a lot of it is a pretty straight forward "scratch in VR" type system or a basic visual lisp editor, but it works pretty well.  Duplicate and move work using the same UI as the world building tools

text: So mainly what got removed and paired back was the actor model inspired message passing system, which is a shame because it would have made object sharing easier, and certain types of decoupled state changes easier

elements.text: So mainly what got removed and paired back was the actor model inspired message passing system, which is a shame because it would have made object sharing easier, and certain types of decoupled state changes easier

text: Message passing still exists, but the only thing that remains is a single send to an explicit object reference.  They also kept connect (probably the only concept that I didn't introduce) which is basically a delegate system.

elements.text: Message passing still exists, but the only thing that remains is a single send to an explicit object reference.  They also kept connect (probably the only concept that I didn't introduce) which is basically a delegate system.

text: I had other ways of doing this built into my initial implementation. Specifically tag messages, which allowed the user to add multiple takes to an object, and send to a tag.  Another thing that they maybe misunderstood? was there is already support for multiple handlers for the same event

elements.text: I had other ways of doing this built into my initial implementation. Specifically tag messages, which allowed the user to add multiple takes to an object, and send to a tag.  Another thing that they maybe misunderstood? was there is already support for multiple handlers for the same event

text: names didn't have to be unique, that might have been a result of poor understanding of the system or something else.  I had to fight a lot of programmer assumptions about... well programming languages.  Like the idea that method names have to be unique in most OO languages.  That constraint doesn't exist in the Horizon language but oh well :slightly_smiling_face:
